awd_titl_txt: Designing and Researching a Program for Preparing Teachers as Facilitators of Computational Making Activities in Classroom and Informal Learning Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study a model of pre-service teacher preparation that is designed to to increase teachers' and students' skills and confidence with computational thinking and develop teachers as designers of inclusive learning environments to promote computational thinking. The project will build teachers' recognition of diverse family learning and cultural resources. The project will engage elementary (grades K-5) pre-service teachers (who are concurrently involved in school-based teacher preparation programs) as facilitators in an existing family technology program called Family Creative Learning (FCL).  This program is embedded in the Denver Public Library (DPL) network of makerspaces. The project will study pre-service elementary teachers' computational thinking and facilitation practices and its impact on children's learning across informal and classroom settings where pre-service teachers concurrently conduct their field work. The project team will develop research-based resources, tools, and activities that help to cultivate these key facilitation practices. These practices will include how to develop trust and relationships, to deepen participation and interests, and to ask questions that encourage inquiry. These resources will be useful for teacher preparation and for staff at informal learning organizations with making and tinkering spaces promoting STEM learning, specifically computational thinking. The project will disseminate resources through current relationships with PBS Kids and through networks of educators such as MakerEd, Connected Learning Alliance, and technology education networks. 

The project will research: (1) what features of pre-service teachers' experiences preparing for and facilitating the FCL program at DPL supports or limits their development of facilitation practices and computational thinking; (2) study how teachers and participants learn and develop in their joint engagement with computational thinking through making; (3) examine how teachers carry over and influence student's learning in their fieldwork within classroom settings. The project team will use ethnographic methods to develop comparative case studies of pre-service teachers' development and the impact on student learning across formal and informal learning settings. These methods include observation, interviews, and artifact collection to closely document what supports new facilitators to engage in facilitation practices of computational thinking activities and its consequential impact on student and family learning. An external advisory board with relevant expertise will provide iterative feedback and assess the project's progress in meeting its goals. The project results have implications for teaching practices across formal and informal learning spaces that aim to engage diverse participants in interest-driven, peer-supported, and project-based STEM learning experiences.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An interdisciplinary team from the Department of Information Science and School of Education at University of Colorado Boulder (CU Boulder) in partnership with Denver Public Library (DPL) designed and studied a model of pre-service teacher preparation that aimed (1) to increase teachers' and students' skills and confidence with computing; (2) to develop teachers as designers of inclusive learning environments cultivating children's computational thinking; (3) to build teachers' recognition of diverse families' learning and cultural resources. In this model, the project team engaged elementary (grades K-5) pre-service teachers as facilitators in a family technology program called Family Creative Learning (FCL) embedded in DPL's network of makerspaces called ideaLABs happening concurrently with school-based teacher preparation through CU Boulder. The project team and DPL focused on engaging students, families, and educators from underrepresented groups in STEM. 

It is common for future teachers to spend time in K-12 classrooms as student teachers, and sometimes, to spend time in out-of-school activities with young people. In our study, pre-service teachers facilitated creative computing workshops with children and families through the FCL program at a DPL makespace. Our study found that future teachers experienced consequential professional learning as they moved back and forth between these two settings where the activities, roles, and norms for STEM learning can differ. 

In particular, future teachers came to understand children and their families in more holistic ways after opportunities to work closely with them in FCL at a library makerspace. For example, teachers were able to notice how adult caregivers supported children's participation in activities by attending to both their understanding of the activity and their affective experience with it. Their observations stood in contrast to the deficit assumption teachers sometimes make that parents do not have expertise in fostering learning for their children. In addition, the teachers developed a deeper understanding of families' relationships as well as their own relationships with families -- opportunities that are often inaccessible to teachers when parents visit their child's classroom for brief and structured parent-teacher conferences or to pick them up at the end of the day. As one teacher shared after observing adult caregivers with their children, "they are whole people too."

Furthermore, engaging in creative learning opportunities with children and families in an out-of-school setting supported teachers to reflect on a dimension of learning that is often under-recognized in classroom environments: affect. Future teachers became more skilled at noticing and responding to the participants' affective experiences, attending to the range of emotions that can emerge in their learning, participation and collaboration. They also reflected on their own emotions while facilitating, saying that the experience gave them a model for how they want their own future classrooms to feel: places of excitement, joy and belonging. 

Finally, future teachers became skillful at seeing how the designs and structures of school-based and out-of-school STEM experiences can make a big difference for how children and family members are positioned as creative and capable with computing. In particular, children and their caregivers were invited to create projects based on stories about their families. Teachers observed children and families pursue projects they felt passionate about, and this passion in turn fueled a desire to learn how to use computational technologies for specific and meaningful purposes. Facilitating the workshops gave the future teachers an opportunity to puzzle alongside children and families as they experimented with creative computing together. Rather than positioning themselves as the "experts" and the families as "novices," there was a spirit of collaboration and shared learning between the facilitators and participants in the workshops.

We have shared outcomes and outputs from the project with relevant gatherings and venues for educators and researchers, which include the Connected Learning Summit, American Educational Researchers Association, and the International Conference of the Learning Sciences. We continue to publish results and to share educator resources on the Family Creative Learning website: https://www.familycreativelearning.org/
